wordpressPost.title: Nothing like a good road trip to get you thinking about life…
wordpressPost.content:
Nothing like a good road trip to get you thinking about life…

This past weekend me and the girls took a nine hour (each way) road trip to Biloxi, Mississippi.

We went to a concert, ate great food, gambled, drank champagne, shopped and had a spa day.  It was fantastic and very relaxing, just what I needed.  Needless to say, like every other weekend, it went by way too fast.

Even though the massage was out of this world and the food was amazing, it was the drive home that I enjoyed the most.

Kind of crazy that I say that because it was the long drive that I was initially dreading.  Let’s face it, four women in a truck that talk too much and who want to stop and pee way to often can get a bit irritating after a couple of hours.

I have been conditioned somewhere along my life to not want to drive, to not enjoy driving and, to hurry and get there no matter what the cost!  I had no appreciation for literally, the journey along the way.

That changed when on the way back from our weekend, I don’t know if the others were tired or just quietly morning the fact that we were heading back to our everyday lives but, it was silent the whole way back.

I was able to think about my life, see the sun setting, see how beautiful the trees actually were and I got to be alone with my thoughts even in the company of others.

I had many real moments where I felt waves of both sadness and happiness come over me.

I’m turning 50 in a couple of months and I’m realizing that I have to make some significant changes in my life that will make my life very uncomfortable for a while but, in the end, the changes are just what I’ve needed to make me happy.

Funny how we fight our thoughts and justify our lives because we go through the day to day motions, filling our spirits with being busy so that maybe, we won’t have to make the decisions that are staring us in the face or whispering in our ear each day.

It’s easy to go on living in a comfort zone that we’re used to because being comfortable feels so good and it’s warm even if, it’s actually the worst thing for us.

For a very long time my spirit was dying and it was screaming for help but I just wouldn’t listen to it.  I pushed the voice down and told myself to shut up and appreciate the life that I had.

Although I appreciate my life and I know others would love to have my life, I also know that right now I have choices and I don’t have to be guilty about wanting to be happy.  The biggest epiphany that I had was realizing that I can’t make others happy.  I can only make myself.  Something I have not done in about ten years.

I’ve always felt responsible for making others happy but I didn’t realize that until I took my road trip.  The cost was more that the money I had left at the casino and I decided I wasn’t going to pay for the rest of my life.

If you don’t get anything else from this blog post, please know and take that statement to heart.  “You can’t make others happy.” And, you are not responsible for making others happy either.  All you can do is be kind and be yourself.

Sometimes all you need is a good road trip to get you thinking about life!
